title: Four inmates are caught after repeatedly escaping a federal prison in Texas for booze and cellphones
text:
Four inmates, who found a way to turn their incarceration at a prison in Texas into a revolving door for alcohol and cellphones, were caught returning to the facility holding the illegal items.

Acting on multiple reports that prisoners were sneaking out and back in to the Federal Prison Complex in Beaumont, Texas, U.S. marshals and sheriff's deputies tracked the inmates.

A spokesperson for the sheriff's office told NBC News that the law enforcement agencies were waiting for them to return to the prison Friday night.

Four inmates were taken back into custody Friday after multiple escapes for whiskey and cellphones

The Federal Prison Complex in Beaumont, where four inmates created a revolving door of escaping for contraband

After exiting the prison grounds, they were spotted cutting through a neighboring ranch. When marshals placed the four men in custody they were carrying bags of contraband, including whiskey and cellphones, NBC News said.

The individuals are identified as Julian Lemus, 34; Leo Martinez, 25; Silevstre Rico, 35; and Robert Young, 45. They were being held in the LaSalle Correctional Facility on charges of escape.

Authorities would not give any details regarding why they are in prison.
description: Four inmates escape and reenter a federal prison in Texas several times. When taken into custody, the prisoners were carrying contraband that included alcohol and cellphones.
